{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3347080,"name":"","username":"delHosp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/delhosp/{size}/221793_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-29T08:34:02.575Z","cooked":"

During this year’s match in Sacramento, in one match, our robot was totally powered off after 1s when the auto began. There was no power before the robot was enabled when we put it on the field.

After the match, we checked the robot on the field, with field volunteers, whether the wiring of the 6AWG cable on PDH, breaker, and Battery. However, no problems were found.

There is one thing that needs to be noticed is that by using a beaker we found that the battery lost 0.5V, and, on the log, PDH read that the voltage dropped from 13V to 9V and

When we took the robot outside the field, we tried to power on the robot with our teammates, it powered successfully. We checked with a mentor from 1678 about the battery with the beaker and used the multimeter to check the shorting issue and the fuse on PDH. Still, no problem was found.

When we came back to China and tried to upgrade the wiring, we found that the rubber of the black line had melted. See the picture below. We had discussed many possibilities, but none of them can explain how can the temperature increase so much in only 1s. Was there any same situation meet in your teams?

PDH Battery Input Hub1920×2560 342 KB

The cable was probably not inserted correctly/all the way, and got a bit loose. At that point, there was a lot of electrical resistance at that spot, which leads to heat generating very quickly. This exact issue happened to us in an off-season comp.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-29T09:05:42.379Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":254,"readers_count":253,"score":70.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":460585,"topic_slug":"pdh-input-hub-wire-melted","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60828,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pdh-input-hub-wire-melted/460585/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3347085,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-29T09:18:45.583Z","cooked":"

Or pushed too far in and locked onto a litle bit of the insulation instead of the bare wire. I almost suspect that here, theory being that the insulation would melt from the heat until the connector locked on properly, then one surge current (from the sudden capacity increase vs demand) knocks out a protection unit. Reboot and it all comes back on.

Either way, “loose connection” is the probable cause pending more information.

Team in San Diego had a loose wire on one of their batteries. They died mid match, FTA took a look, felt the wire and said “this is your problem, the terminal is loose and the wire is warm. Fix it and the rest of the issues you’re having will likely go away.”

Yeahhhh, had this happen to my team 2 weeks ago and check it on every bot since. Somewhere in the docs it gives you strip lengths (3/4in for this cable) and there is a NEW warning against pushing it in further than it should in which this could happen.

The exact same thing was found in a robot at the New England Waterbury event. The working theory is that the strip length was a bit too short. With that type of terminal, a bit too long will work better than a bit too short.
